title: IT Department Password Reset
description: A convincing email from the IT department requesting a mandatory password update through a lookalike portal.
context: You work at a company that recently announced it would be upgrading its security systems. You receive this email during business hours on a Monday morning.

content.subject: Action Required: Mandatory Password Update - Security Compliance
content.body_html:
Dear Employee,

As part of our ongoing security infrastructure upgrade (ref: SEC-2024-0892), all employees are required to update their network passwords by end of business today.

This is a mandatory security compliance requirement. Failure to update your password may result in temporary account suspension during the migration window.

Please use the secure portal below to update your credentials:

https://company-itsupport.com/password-reset

If you experience any issues, contact the Help Desk at ext. 4500.

Thank you for your cooperation.

Best regards,
Michael Chen
Information Security Analyst
IT Security Team
Extension: 4502

This message is confidential and intended solely for the addressee. If you received this in error, please delete it immediately.

red_flags.label: Lookalike sender domain
red_flags.detail: The email comes from 'company-itsupport.com' instead of 'company.com'. Attackers register similar-looking domains to appear internal.

red_flags.label: Password reset link goes to external domain
red_flags.detail: The reset link is on 'company-itsupport.com', not the company's actual domain. Internal IT would use internal systems.

red_flags.label: End-of-day deadline creates pressure
red_flags.detail: While less extreme than '24 hours', the tight deadline is still designed to prevent you from verifying through other channels.

red_flags.label: Threat of account suspension
red_flags.detail: The threat of suspension during a 'migration window' adds pressure. Legitimate IT teams provide longer timelines and multiple reminders.

red_flags.label: Generic greeting instead of your name
red_flags.detail: Real internal IT emails typically address you by name. 'Dear Employee' suggests a mass-targeted attack.

actions.label: Click the link and update your password
actions.feedback: This link leads to a credential harvesting page that captures your current and new password. The attacker now has access to your account.

actions.label: Forward to colleagues to make sure they see it
actions.feedback: Forwarding phishing emails spreads the attack further within the organization. Never forward suspicious emails to others.

actions.label: Call the IT Help Desk using the company directory number
actions.feedback: Excellent! Verifying through a known, trusted channel (not the number in the email) is the gold standard response. Use numbers from the company directory.

actions.label: Report the email to IT security via official channels
actions.feedback: Perfect! Reporting to IT security through official channels helps them investigate and warn other employees.
